subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Reading practice - The Raven
msgSnippet: ... Hi Paul, I just got around to reading this today. I am not the most perfect candidate for seeing problem in the text because I once memorized The Raven,
messageBody:
Paul wrote:
>
>
> FYI: I have uploaded to the files a copy of Poe's The Raven I
> transcribed into QS. I used the converter and went through to change a
> few things and clean up in general. My next project is more ambitious:
> Jules Verne - 20,000 Leagues Under The Sea
>
> Project Gutenberg has plenty of public domain texts in digital format,
> and I plan on going through any that interest me.
>
> Related to recent posts, I will clarify that I did not use 34 in the
> text. I suppose I am odd in that my pronunciation of "on" would use
> 33, but "ox" would use 32 ("calm" would also be 33", go figure). So, I
> have simply avoided using 34 at all. BYW, I was born and raised in
> central Virginia, but don't have much of a "southern" accent.
>
> Hope everyone enjoys it, and please let me know of any thing you feel
> needs correcting. I went over it several times, but I know I'm not
> perfect.
>

Hi Paul,

I just got around to reading this today. I am not the most perfect
candidate for seeing problem in the text because I once memorized "The
Raven," so I can guess what the words mean without looking at them
closely, and because I am new to QS.

Mainly I found almost no mistakes in the poem and could sound out hte
difficult words I had forgotten.

Here's what I think are mistakes:

1. Shouldn't you use Thither for "the," "Valve" for "of," "Tut" for "to"
and "It" for "if?" I have come to expect these one letter abbreviations
(which Read said were a part of QS) when I read a text. I actually
changed all of these words before I printed out the poem so I could read
it easier.

2. line 10: you spell "borrow" with the "Ah," which made the words hard
for me to decipher. I expected "On," or "Awl."

3. line 12. The words "for evermore" should be joined? I found them
joined in one Gutenberg text.

4. line 33 (and others, too). You spell "shall" with "Ash." I expected
"Ado," so had a hard time reading the word.

5 line 39 (and others). You spell not with "Ah." I expected "Awl" or
"On," so was a bit confused.

6. line 40. You have the wrong word. You use an "and" between "lord" and
"lady" when it should be "or."

7. Line 47 You spell ghastly with "Ash," but I expected "Ah." (Is that
just my Boston accent?)

8. line 50 You spell the "not" in cannot with "Ah." I expected "Awl."

9. line 65: You spell "songs" with an "Ah." I expected "On," or "Awe."

10. line 70. You spell "ominous" with "Ah." I expected "On," or "Awe."

11. line 89. You spell "balm" with "Awl," but I expected "Ah." (My
Boston accent again?)

12. line 93. You spell "sorrow" with "Ah," when I expected "Awl" or "On."


I see you used my Shawtwo font. How flattering! However, I have changed
the name of the font to "Thoth," which you can download in the files
section. Since Shawtwo isn't on my system, the document opened and
displayed TO. I actually typeset the document with TeX and produced a
PDF and was thinking of putting it in the text areas on my sourceforge
site, with your permission, of course. The PDF version looks much better
than the RTF version because the font is kerned correctly, and with PDF
anyone can open the document and see it correctly, regardless of what
fonts they have on their system.

Paul
